name: Daily standups
description: Having a daily standup each day helps us prepare to have the best possible day.

name: Pairing
description: Pairing helps collaboration and knowledge transfer within the team.

name: Team Exploratory Testing Sessions
description: Team exploratory testing helps us gain deep feedback on development work.

name: Lightweight Architecure Decision Records
description: Much documentation can be replaced with highly readable code and tests. In a world of evolutionary architecture, however, it's important to record certain design decisions for the benefit of future team members as well as for external oversight. Lightweight Architecture Decision Records is a technique for capturing important architectural decisions along with their context and consequences. We store these details in source control, instead of a wiki or website, as then they can provide a record that remains in sync with the code itself.

name: Pull Request Templates
description: PR templates can pre-populate a pull request with a list of things to check before the PR is merged.

name: Mob Programming
description: Mob Programming is a software development approach where the whole team works on the same thing, at the same time, in the same space, and at the same computer. The SQL Prompt team experimented with it and found it to be very useful for understanding different team members approaches, how they code, to learn together and to some extent, a team bonding experience. The Orcas also used 'mobbing by default' during their first few months as a team and found it really effective. Following on from Woody Zuill's workshop on the subject, most if not all of the teams in Product and Foundry are looking to do more mob programming.

name: Domain-driven Design
description: Domain-driven Design (DDD) is a development approach that deeply values the domain model and connects it to the implementation. DDD gives us the opportunity to keep ourselves honest about striving for persistence ignorance by abstrating the consistency boundaries through proper domain modeling. We are finding it easy to shape the discussions around business language and structure the codebase around the well-established DDD concepts such as Aggregate, Command, Event, etc. There is a also great deal of resource and community support behind this approach which makes it easy to acquire the knowladge. Being explored by The Spiders.

name: Property-based testing
description: Property-based testing is a technique of writing tests in a manner where you express the property (characteristic) of the component. You don't provide particular values as an input, but usually, you let a sophisticated framework to generate a lot of test cases (usually limited to 100 by default) from all possible range of input and algorithm tries to find as fast as possible a fail case. Being explored by DataMasker team and we are using FsCheck to do it.

name: Isolated installer tests
description: Automated tests that install in an isolated VM gives confidence that build is actually releasable. Ideally, both a clean install, and an upgrade install from the previous release, to ensure the installer works for both new and existing users.

name: C# 8
description: We build our software using C#. We try to keep up to date with the latest version of C# possible as new language features help us write simpler code.

name: C++
description: C++ was the right tool for the job in the past.

name: Delphi
description: SQL Backup engine is written in Delphi.

name: JavaScript (pre ES6)
description: We don't use older versions of JavaScript. ES6 features like promises, modules and classes significantly improve the JavaScript experience, and tools like BabelJS allow us to adopt this with confidence. We will update older JavaScript implementations when possible, but will not actively retire them across our codebase.

name: JavaScript (ES6+)
description: We use JavaScript for rapid prototyping of ideas because it allows us to go faster. In code bases where we already have significant JavaScript we will continue to use modern JavaScript.

name: TypeScript
description: TypeScript provides an advanced type system on top of JavaScript. We have a preference for TypeScript in production code because the optional type safety can help and improved tool support.

name: NUnit 2
description: NUnit is our default framework for writing unit and integration tests. NUnit 2 is working well in most projects that use it, but consider upgrading to NUnit 3 for newer features.

name: NUnit 3
description: NUnit is our default framework for writing unit and integration tests. We use NUnit 3 by default for new projects.

name: Pester
description: Pester is our default framework for writing tests in PowerShell. We use Pester by default for new PowerShell tests.

name: Balsamiq
description: Balsamiq gives us the ability to create quick low-fidelity wireframes to describe workflows.

name: Git
description: Git is our defacto VCS, and all repositories are stored on GitHub.

name: OneDrive
description: OneDrive is our default choice for storing Office documents to share within the organization. In the last three years, Microsoft have done a lot of work on OneDrive and the associated sync clients and have closed the gap on their competitors. The sync client is very stable and doesn’t contain the restrictions that it did before.

name: Raygun error reporting
description: Raygun allows loosely-coupled error reporting to a web endpoint. Raygun offers other capabilities too, but we only use the error reporting. Ideally our choice of error provider would be a server-side decision, but RedGate.Usage.Client doesn't currently support error reporting

name: Google Drive
description: We don’t have corporate Google accounts and it doesn’t make sense to subscribe to both GSuite and Office 365, both for cost reasons and from an information management point of view. The fact that we don’t have corporate accounts means data can’t be removed from Google accounts when someone leaves the company (as we don’t own the account), so we shouldn’t be storing any personal information (such as customer data) in Google Drive.

name: SmartAssembly
description: SmartAssembly obfuscation, error and usage reporting becomes tightly-coupled to products and slows down builds.

name: Windows 7+/2008R2+
description: Our default supported operating system is Windows. If Microsoft continues to support this as part of their default support package we continue to support running our applications on that OS. See https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/13853/windows-lifecycle-fact-sheet

name: Chrome
description: Chrome is Google's evergreen browser. We support it by default.

name: Firefox
description: Firefox is Mozilla's evergreen browser. We support it by default.

name: Edge
description: Edge is Microsoft's evergreen browser. We support it by default.

name: IE 11
description: IE 11 is the default browser on Windows 10 and makes up approximately 8% of the visits to Redgate.com. It is also the only browser available by default on the server versions of Windows (including Windows Server 2019). Even though, for new products, it does not need to be supported. For products that are supporting IE 11 and feeling the pain, the next major version is the point you can drop the support (when confirmed with the Product Owner). Consider supporting IE 11 for admin interfaces or initial setup that is supposed to be done directly on the server.

name: IE 10 and under
description: We do not support IE10 and under. Any implementation to support IE10 can be removed, but there is no strong drive to do so across our codebase.

name: Raven DB
description: We previously used Raven DB in DLM Dashboard but our experience was not positive.

name: Fakes
description: We've experimented using Fakes in the Redgate Usage Client - fakes used in the test can reduce the amount of mocking is required and can make the tests simpler.

name: Wix 3
description: Windows Installer XML Toolset 3 (WiX), is a free software toolset that builds Windows Installer packages from XML. We only use Wix v3.

name: Inno Setup
description: SQL Backup uses divergent installer technology.

name: RedGate.Usage.Client
description: Redgate's standard tool for Product and Feature usage reporting.

name: AppInsights
description: Microsoft's platform for data analysis.

name: MixPanel
description: Tool for presenting analytic data. Now superseded by AppInsights. We will review whether to retire this when Application Insights has a configurable retention period.

name: Google Analytics
description: Tool for presenting analytic data. Now superseded by AppInsights.

name: SonarQube
description: Sonarqube provides automated code review, highlighting quality issues in changing code. This feedback is best surfaced through automated PR comments.

name: RedGate.Build
description: Redgate's standardised, scripted infrastructure for building products. Based on build-script-templates.

name: Custom build scripts
description: Builds scripts that diverge from RedGate.Build. These were useful when first made, but we should move to sandard RedGate.Build when possible.

name: Build magic
description: Legacy build tooling, now to be deprecated in favour of RedGate.Build.

name: Vagrant
description: Vagrant is an open-source software product for building and maintaining portable virtual software development environments. We use Vagrant with Puppet to provision test environments and internal infrastructure.

name: Puppet
description: Puppet is an open-source software configuration management tool. We use Vagrant with Puppet to provision test environments and internal infrastructure.

name: DevCloud
description: DevCloud is an internal platform for hosting short-lived virtual machines.

name: Long-lived Virtual Machines
description: We avoid using long-lived virtual machines, especially those that cannotbe trivially rebuilt on demand.

name: Docker (for building products around)
description: Docker is a tool designed to make it easier to create, deploy, and run applications by using containers. Currently being explored by Whitesharks.

name: Docker (for distributing products)
description: Docker makes distributing and consuming products much easier for our customers, although it does raise some questions around licensing.

name: Docker (for build/test environments)
description: Containerizing build/test environments makes builds more consistent and reduces the dependency on specific build agent environments. Currently being explored by Team Orca.

name: Kubernetes
description: Kubernetes is an open-source container-orchestration system for automating deployment, scaling and management of containerized applications. Currently being explored by Whitesharks.

name: Renovate
description: Renovate is a tool for automatically updating third party dependencies (such as those from nuget and npm). Using it enables continuous integration of a project's dependencies and reduces the time spent performing manual dependency updates. This is being explored by the Ambassadors, Spiders and Prompt teams.

name: Dependabot
description: Dependabot is a tool for automatically updating third party dependencies (such as those from nuget and npm), which has been aquired by Github and is being integrated with the platform. Using it enables continuous integration of a project's dependencies and reduces the time spent performing manual dependency updates. This is being explored with repositories that use supported package management tools, such as honeycomb.

name: Lucidchart
description: Diagramming tool that allows drawing architectural diagrams in a team environment. Also allows integration with OneDrive, Confluence, etc. Currently being explored by The Spiders team.

name: draw.io
description: Simple Open source diagramming tool that allows drawing architectural diagrams. Also allows integration with OneDrive, Jira, Confluence, etc. Currently being explored by the Prompt team (for C4 diagrams).

name: CEF
description: Chromium Embedded framework (CEF) is an open source framework for embedding a web browser engine inside other tools. This was explored, but proved unsuccessful for Redgate. It's only used in SQL Doc, but we have no plans to actively replace it.

name: Winforms
description: Winforms is a legacy UI library in the .NET Framework. Maybe Redgate products already use Winforms, but we prefer other tools for new development.

name: WPF
description: Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) s a graphical subsystem provided with the .NET Framework. It's one of our prefered desktop UI technologies, especially when embedding products inside Visual Studio or SSMS.

name: Electron
description: Electron is an open-source desktop UI framework. It's developed/maintained by GitHub, and used by Microsoft for VS Code. It's one of our prefered desktop UI technologies, especially for standalone desktop tools.

name: Check for Updates (CfU)
description: Redgate's established mechanism for distributing product upgrades. The update process is manual and intrusive for users, leading to slow version uptake and version fragmentation in production. We're keen to explore alternatives.

name: Release Management: User-controlled background updates
description: Allowing a user to kick off a background upgrade of products, from the UI. The only drawback of the current mechanism is the lack of support for changelogs and alerts for breaking changes. Being explored by ICloneable<Sheep> on SQL Clone.

name: Oracle database
description: Oracle database is a strong rival to SQL Server. Redgate has legacy tools for this suite (Oracle Compare & Source Control), and the space is under ongoing investigation by Foundry (with support from TKomp).

name: SQL Server on Linux
description: SQL Server has had growing support on Linux for some time, but Linux is not a platform that Redgate actively targets. Current windows-based tools support connecting to a SSoL database, and further value is being explored in Foundry.

name: Azure DB Studio
description: Azure DB Studio is Microsoft's aspirational replacement for SSMS. Potential Redgate tooling support is being investigated by Foundry.

name: SQL Change Automation
description: Redgate SQL Change Automation is our commerical offering to help people manage the state of databases as part of application deployment. We should investigate if/how to use our own tools as part of our development activities. Versioning Teams to investigate this by looking at how CORE manage databases.

name: React
description: React is our web framework of choice. It's popular, it's easy to understand and it's got great tooling support.

name: Honeycomb Web Toolkit
description: Honeycomb is our design system and the web toolkit makes adopting this in your own projects easy.

name: Webpack
description: Webpack is a module bundler. It's main purpose is to bundle JavaScript files for usage in a browser.

name: Babel
description: Babel is a JavaScript compiler allowing you to confidently use the latest JavaScript features in all browsers.

name: Enzyme
description: Enzyme is a JavaScript Testing utility for React that makes it easier to assert, manipulate and traverse your React Components' output.

name: Redux
description: Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript apps. We recommend this when state management becomes complicated with React alone.

name: Release Management: Release scripts
description: Using a single powershell script (basic-release.ps1 or using RG.Release) to manage your entire release process is a good trade off between saving effort, and security and accountability for each release.

name: Continuous Delivery
description: From Accelerate: a development practice where software is in a deployable state throughout its lifecycle, and the team prioritizes keeping the software in a deployable state over working on new features. Fast feedback on the quality and deployability of the system is available to all team members, and when they get reports that the system isn't deployable, fixes are made quickly. Finally, the system can be deployed to production or end users at any time, on demand.

name: Octopus Deploy (internal deployments)
description: Octopus Deploy is used for deploying software within Redgate. Whenever we deploy something running on Redgate's infrastructure, it should be deployed through Octopus. This can be configured with ITOps.

name: Trello
description: Some teams use Trello for issue management and digital taskboards. Setup and administration are cheap, but issue management capabilities are limited.

name: Jira
description: Some teams use Jira for issue management and digital taskboards. The setup and administration costs are higher than other tools, but issue management capabilities are rich.

name: GitHub Issues
description: Some teams use GitHub issues for issue management and digital taskboards. Setup and administration are slightly costlier than Trello, while issue management capabilties are limited. Integration with source code and repositories can be valuable, but is also complex for multi-repository projects.

name: Physical whiteboards
description: Some teams use physical whiteboards for issue management and a physical taskboard. Costs are variable dependent on the setup and how the tool is used but can be minimal. Issue management and audit capabiltiies are minimal.

name: .NET Framework 4.7.2
description: We continue to build our products using the .NET framework, but future development should target .NET Standard or .NET Core if possible.

name: .NET Standard 2.0
description: Microsoft has delivered a cross-platform future. New applications should be built to conform to .NET Standard by default.

name: .NET Core 3.0
description: Microsoft has delivered a cross-platform future. New applications should be built with .NET Core by default whenever possible. .NET Core doesn't yet support WPF/Winforms applications, but we're hopeful for support in .NET Core 3.

name: SSMS 2012 and above
description: SQL Server Management Studio 2012 and above are supported my Microsoft, so we should support them in our tools.

name: SQL Server 2008 and above
description: SQL Server 2008 and above are supported by Microsoft, so we should support them in our tools.

name: Retrospectives
description: Regular retrospectives help us gain feedback to improve our development teams

name: Redgate Installer
description: Redgate Installer is our standard installer which we should use in preference to other installer technologies because it allows us to ship products together, provides a consistent experience, and integrates with our release, licensing and update systems.

name: TeamCity
description: We build all of our projects on TeamCity because it's simpler to use one CI system across the company. Our use of build scripts rather than complex TeamCity configuration reduces coupling of our builds to TeamCity itself.

name: Prettier
description: Prettier automates consistent code styling for web languages by providing as few formatting options as possible.

name: Dogfooding
description: As a general principle we should use our own tools to solve problems. This process is known as dog-fooding. We should do this even if we feel our products don't solve our own problems perfectly because doing so is the best way to learn how to improve our products.

name: Java
description: Typically we don't use Java, but we will when necessary. Examples include the SQL Change Automation plugins for TeamCity, Bamboo and Jenkins.

name: PowerShell Core 6
description: For internal automation we use PowerShell Core 6.

name: PowerShell 3+
description: When we are writing cmdlets for external use we target PowerShell 3.

name: JSON
description: For storing user information, such as settings we want to use a textual format. The choice boils down to JSON or XML. We prefer JSON because it's less verbose.

name: XML
description: For storing user information we used to use XML. We'll continue to use that, but avoid it in the future because it's very verbose. We perceive the cost of migration away to be high enough for this to be Endure, rather than Retire.

name: Registry
description: We avoid storing settings in the Registry as it's Windows specific. However, it does make it easier for system administrators to apply group policy so we should bear this in mind when choosing setting locations.

name: Technical spikes
description: Timeboxed prototype/proof-of-concept for some feature or technical implementation detail. Usually done with minimal quality (since they're never intended to be real code), implemented on a branch and then thrown away.

name: Feature flags
description: A mechanism to prevent code in master from affecting the way the product behaves. There are lots of different types of flags/toggles: they might be set at compile or run time; they might be purely internal or visible to the user, and so on.

name: Kanban
description: Flow-based agile framework the emphasises limiting work-in-progress (WIP). Historically adopted by teams who find time-boxed iterations restrictive, or need to work in a more reactive manner.

name: Zero bugs policy
description: A zero-bug policy does not mean bug-free code production; it means striving to eradicate all known bugs.

name: Karma
description: Karma is a test runner for JavaScript which spawns a web server that executes source code against test code for each of the browsers connected.

name: jasmine
description: Jasmine is a BDD framework for testing JavaScript code. The Monitor team are using it through Karma.

name: nightwatch
description: Nightwatch is an end-to-end testing solution for browser-based apps using WebDriver. We are using this for BDD assertions.

name: jest
description: Jest is a way to test all JavaScript code that's used by Facebook. COREDev have a non-trivial amount of tests over multiple projects that use jest.

name: mocha
description: mocha is a feature rich test framework running on Node/Browser. We believe Jasmine/Jest are better alternatives, but tolorate existing mocha tests.

name: chai
description: We preferred to use Jest instead of Chai for BDD/TDD assertions.

name: Definition of Done
description: Scrum says that 'when ... is described as 'Done', everyone must understand what 'Done' means'. By agreeing up front what constitutes 'done' for a feature / story it can highlight any misunderstandings over what is expected from the story. The definition can also help ensure basic quality and ancillary tasks are completed e.g. documentation is updated. Tested across all operating systems / database versions etc. The Versioning teams will be trying to do this.

name: Ranorex
description: Ranorex is a commercial GUI test automation framework that was used for various Redgate products in the past. It only remains in-use with SQL Source Control, and should not be adopted any further.

name: UIAutomation/System.Windows.Automation
description: UI Automation is an accessibility framework, while System.Windows.Automation supports automation of WPF clients. Microsoft recommend use of Appium and WinAppDriver rather than building your own automation framework with these tools.

name: Appium with WinAppDriver
description: WinAppDriver is a service to support Selenium-like UI Test Automation on Windows Applications. It is Microsoft's recommendation for automated UI-driven functional testing for Windows applications.

name: ReSpeller using AmE
description: ReSpeller is a spell-checking engine integrated with ReSharper. We use American English to be consistent with .NET Framework and other 3rd party libraries. Additional words are stored in a solution team-shared settings file (*.sln.DotSettings).

name: Time-based estimation
description: We've found time-based estimation to be costly, difficult to be accurate with, and difficult to apply to non-repeatable tasks. Broad brush estimates, such as 'few days', 'couple of weeks', 'month or more', can be useful to set expectations with non technical people.

name: User Stories
description: User stories are short, simple description of a feature as described from the perspective of end users. They typically follow a simple template, As a X, I want Y to achieve Z. Both Versioning & Automation and the Prompt are using this approach.

name: Open API specification
description: Our public web-based APIs are exposed through the Open API specification interface as being the description for REST APIs, which allows both humans and computers to discover and understand the capabilities of a service without requiring access to source code, additional documentation, or inspection of network traffic.

name: Value Stream Mapping
description: Value Stream mapping is a technique to visualize the steps needed in a process. By doing so we can use a systems thinking mindset to look for optimizations and perform small experiments to learn what to optimize. The Oracle/V&A teams will look at exploring this technique.

name: Automated Code Style Settings
description: Each team should automate their coding style using a team shared R# settings file.

name: Stop the line when master is red
description: A red build of the master branch should be teams' top priority. When it happens, all the work in a team halts and team members agree who is fixing it. This ensures that the problem is visible and it's the whole team's responsibility to solve it. This approach also encourages teams to fix flaky tests.

name: Vertical slicing
description: We aim to deliver work in small, vertical slices. This enables regular delivery of working software, faster feedback from early adopters, and gradual learning as we incrementally deliver richer capabiltiies.

name: Iteration planning
description: We plan work in iterations to align on a short term goal. This allows teams to build a shared understanding of the work, discuss necessary tasks, and identify dependencies between those tasks.

name: Frequent update release channels
description: Allowing users to opt-in to more regular product updates, allowing quicker feedback for Redgate, while maintaining a slower-cadence release channel for other users. This is in-place with SQL Source Control and SQL Compare, but we prefer simpler releasing mechanisms ('Single release channel') and leaving control in the hands of the user.

name: Single release channel
description: Notifying all licensed users of all product updates, allowing users granualar control of their environments while enabling potentially wider-ranging feedback for Redgate.

name: Private builds
description: Shipping a release that isn't publically available to all users, typically for feedback from a specific customer. We prefer other delivery mechanisms for getting this feedback, like improved logging and feature flagging in public releases, rather than version fragmentation. Putting these in place can be time-consuming, so we endure using private builds where necessary.

name: Beta/Early Access programmmes
description: Working with a self-selected group of users to get feedback on product development. This has been explored in the past, but may not be under active investigation now.

name: Concierge users
description: Close feedback loops with selected customers to give rich feedback on product development. This is being explored with SQL Change Automation in SSMS.

name: Outcome-focussed OKRs
description: We believe Outcome-focussed OKRs are a really important piece of the puzzle to set teams up with clarity of purpose and linking work to a higher aim (important aspects of team motivation and engagement as called out in Dan Pink's Drive). More details about how we currently frame OKRs can be found here.

name: RESTful APIs
description: RESTful APIs are an architectural style that defines a set of constraints for creating web services. We follow the Microsoft guidelines on RESTful services.

name: Gamestorming / Liberating structures
description: The ideation, decision-making and exploration games/activities described in Gamestorming and Liberating Structures have proved to be very successful ways to help teams and wider groups engage with difficult and thoughtful topics. They balance different styles of input (more/less gregarious people, more confident/reticent people, etc) and help groups come up with better, more robust ideas than any individual could on their own.

name: Theory of Constraints
description: The Theory of Constraints is a method for identifying the most important limiting factor (i.e. constraint) that stands in the way of achieving a goal and then systematically improving that constraint until it is no longer the limiting factor. In manufacturing, the constraint is often referred to as a bottleneck. The application of this method in a software dev environment has a demonstrable benefit to task lead times, reduction in waste and, basically, deliver the most valuable stuff to users quicker. Dev Leads team will be running workshops (and, we hope, a book club) to help teams explore how applying the ToC can help them deliver the most valuable stuff to users quicker.

name: Impact Mapping
description: Impact Mapping is a planning technique. It focuses on desired impacts and outcomes over the detail of how those outcomes will be achieved. This is being investigated by the Oracle team.

name: ASP.NET Core
description: ASP.NET Core should be the default for new web-based projects.

name: ASP.NET 4.x
description: ASP.NET 4.x and below should be retired (slowly as it's a major undertaking). New development is on ASP.NET Core, and future versions of ASP.NET will only support .NET Core so it makes sense to retire this in products we expect to stick around.

name: Chocolatey
description: Chocolatey is a package manager for Windows. We use this internally to install tools such as Vagrant and Virtual Box and as part of our test infrastructure.

name: OWASP Dependency-Check
description: Dependency-Check is a Software Composition Analysis (SCA) tool that attempts to detect publicly disclosed vulnerabilities contained within a project's dependencies. Its value to Redgate is being explored by the coaches and the Toolbelt Team.

name: Postman
description: Postman is an API development environment. Currently being explored by the versioning teams.

name: KeePass
description: KeePass allows to store all passwords in one encrypted file in GitHub, so you need to care about one master password only, rather than multiple passwords to multiple resources.

name: Semantic UI
description: Semantic UI is a library of web controls for modern web development, similar to Bootstrap, that has an official React library.

name: honeycomb-semantic-ui-theme
description: An NPM package to theme Semantic UI in the style of Honeycomb.

name: Semantic Versioning
description: Semantic Versioning is a de-facto industry standard for versioning applications. We should strive to use it, at least for internal libraries. For user-facing products SemVer may conflict with marketing needs.

name: ActiPro WPF controls
description: ActiPro is a set of WPF controls. Currently being used in SQL Prompt, SQL Multiscript, ANTS Profiler and Oracle Tools.

name: Hybrid boards
description: Hybrid boards are an attempt to model the reality of complex work onto a Kanban-like board. They are being explored by the SQL Prompt team and Provisioning teams.

name: Monthly Show & Tell
description: A monthly Show & Tell lets Redgate's development teams share the progress they are making towards their goals, and the lessons they've learnt.

name: Quarterly Expo
description: A quarterly expo lets all Redgate's development teams share their achievements, answer questions, take feedback, and show upcoming work. Everyone in our Cambridge office is envited, to get to know our teams a bit better and share their perspective on our products.

name: Team retrospectives
description: Teams should regularly self-inspect and plan for how to improve how they work (a practice popularised by Scrum.

name: Iteration planning
description: Intentionally planning a bounded iteration of work, typically timeboxed. A practice popularised by Scrum. We default to this approach to encourage iterative delivery in teams. An alternative to a pull-based approach (ref: Kanban)

name: Polly
description: Polly is a .NET library that provides resilience and transient-fault handling capabilities. You can implement those capabilities by applying Polly policies such as Retry, Circuit Breaker, Bulkhead Isolation, Timeout, and Fallback. Currently being explored by the Toolbelt Team

name: Four Key Metrics
description: The thorough State of DevOps reports have focused on data-driven and statistical analysis of high-performing organizations. The result of this multiyear research, published in Accelerate, demonstrates a direct link between organizational performance and software delivery performance. The researchers have determined that only four key metrics differentiate between low, medium and high performers: lead time, deployment frequency, mean time to restore (MTTR) and change fail percentage. We are instrumenting our build pipelines to track these metrics at Redgate to learn how we can use them to drive performance improvements. The metrics themselves are available internally at acceleratemetrics.red-gate.com.

name: Keel
description: An open source project to update kubernetes containers to the latest image when a new version is found in a container registry. See Keel

name: Helm
description: 'The package manager for Kubernetes'. An open source project to deploy and update kubernetes applications with multiple resources via Helm charts.

name: Prometheus
description: A CNCF graduated monitoring and timeseries database for Kuberenetes. See Prometheus

name: Grafana
description: 'Grafana is the open source analytics & monitoring solution for every database'. An open source dashboarding project that can integrate with many data source, including Prometheus. See Grafana

name: Loki
description: 'Loki is a logging backend, optimized for users running Prometheus and Kubernetes.' An open source log aggregation project for applications running in Kubernetes. See Loki

name: System.Data.SQLClient
description: System.Data.SQLClient is the .NET Framework library for connecting to SQL Server. It's not .NET Core compatible and the advice from Microsoft is to switch to Microsoft.Data.SqlClient. However it's not ready just yet, so (for now) this is in Endure

name: Microsoft.Data.SQLClient
description: Microsoft.Data.SQLClient is the new cross-platform library recommended by Microsoft to use across .NET Core and .NET Framework applications. It's under active development at the moment, but is clearly described as the future. SCA is tracking the progress of this.

name: Roslyn-based code analyzers
description: The Roslyn-based Analyzers analyze projects' source code to find issues and suggest corrections. They work both interactively and during builds. They're normally easy to introduce and give valueable feedback on the spot. Some analyzers that we adopted are Security Code Scan, Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.Analyzers, Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Api.Analyzers, Microsoft.DotNet.Analyzers.Compatibility, NSubstitute.Analyzers.CSharp, FluentAssertions.Analyzers.
